item.title: Winner in Arkansas Takes $1.817 Billion Powerball Jackpot
item.description: A single ticket drawn Wednesday night won the second-largest U.S. lottery jackpot ever.
item.dc:creator: Dan Watson

media:content.media:description: An advertisement for Powerball in Manhattan on Monday. On Christmas Eve, one Powerball ticket in Arkansas delivered a gift worth $1.817 billion.

item.title: La triste Navidad familiar de Kate Winslet
item.description: ‘Adiós, June’, el debut como directora de la actriz británica, se basa en un guion escrito por su hijo y sigue a una familia fracturada que visita a la matriarca moribunda en el hospital durante las fiestas.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Stanford and Thea Traff

media:content.media:credit: Thea Traff for The New York Times

item.title: Christmas Dinner Can Feel Endless. Embrace It.
item.description: A long-neglected one-act from a theatrical master offers the key to enjoying your family gatherings.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy McCarter

item.title: I’ve Been the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees for a Decade. This Is the Crisis I See.
item.description: Populist rhetoric is numbing us to the plight of others.
item.dc:creator: Filippo Grandi
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees

item.title: ​North Korea Unveils the Completed Hull of What It Calls a Nuclear Submarine
item.description: The debut followed the North’s first test of a new surface-to-air missile and the arrival of a U.S. nuclear-powered attack sub for a port call in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun

media:content.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media on Thursday showed the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un visiting the manufacturing site of what it said was a nuclear-powered submarine, at an undisclosed location.

item.title: Who’s the Parasite Now? This Newly Discovered ‘Fairy Lantern’ Flower.
item.description: Found in a forest outside Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, the plant steals nutrients from subterranean fungi.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Main

item.title: Why China, a One-Party State, Is Backing Elections in This Country
item.description: The vote in Myanmar, widely seen as a sham, is a bid for legitimacy by the military government. It is also a way for Beijing to exert its influence there.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and David Pierson
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

media:content.media:credit: Pool photo by Andres Martinez Casares
media:content.media:description: A bilateral meeting between leaders of Myanmar and China in the Guest House of Tianjin, China, in August.

item.title: Trump aparece en los nacimientos de Navidad en Nápoles
item.description: En Nápoles, los artesanos llevan generaciones construyendo escenas del nacimiento de Jesús, y a veces incluyen figuras de celebridades. Este año, Trump es una de las más populares.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich

media:content.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Figuras del presidente Trump al estilo de los presepi italianos en una tienda de Nápoles, Italia.

item.title: What Parents in China See in A.I. Toys
item.description: A video of a child crying over her broken A.I. chatbot stirred up conversation in China, with some viewers questioning whether the gadgets are good for children. But the girl’s father says it’s more than a toy; it’s a family member.
item.dc:creator: Jiawei Wang

item.title: Murray Hill and Michelle Cathey-Casino Marry During “A Murray Little Christmas” at Lincoln Center
item.description: The actor and drag king hosts “A Murray Little Christmas” each year. At this year’s Lincoln Center performance, he married Michelle Cathey-Casino.
item.dc:creator: Tammy LaGorce and Ye Fan

media:content.media:description: Michelle Cathey-Casino and Murray Hill were married at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center on Dec. 20. The two met when Mr. Murray had a hair crisis in 2021 and needed Ms. Cathey-Casino’s rescuing.

item.title: Why Russia Is Likely to Reject the New US-Ukrainian Peace Plan
item.description: The first draft essentially called for Ukraine’s surrender. The revised version includes the security guarantees Kyiv wants to prevent future Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko

media:content.media:description: A resident at an apartment building hit by a Russian drone during an aerial attack in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Corrections: Dec. 25, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 25, 2025.

item.title: Quote of the Day: ESCAPE FROM THE ABYSS
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 25, 2025.

item.title: Kennedy Center’s Christmas Eve Jazz Show Canceled After Trump Name Added to Building
item.description: Chuck Redd, a jazz musician, said he canceled his annual concert after President Trump’s name was affixed to the Washington building’s facade.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: An annual Christmas Eve jazz concert was canceled by its host after President Trump’s name was added to the Kennedy Center building.

item.title: NYT Crossword Hints for Dec. 25, 2025
item.description: Sam Ezersky will have you cracking up.
item.dc:creator: Deb Amlen

media:content.media:description: Right this way to Sam Ezersky’s entertaining puzzle.

item.title: Former Broadway Child Actress, 25, Killed in New Jersey Stabbing
item.description: Imani Dia Smith, who appeared in “The Lion King,” died after she was stabbed at a home in Edison, the authorities said. A man faces murder charges related to the incident.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker

item.title: Peng Peiyun, 95, Dies; Official Renounced China’s One-Child Policy
item.description: She was given the “hardest job under heaven”: upholding birth limits enforced by often brutal local officials. She came to support softening the policy, then abolishing it.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley

media:content.media:description: Put in charge of imposing birth limits on Chinese couples, Peng Peiyun, a mother herself, worked to relax the policy by appealing directly to the country’s leaders.

item.title: Man Shot in ICE Confrontation in Maryland, Officials Say
item.description: Federal and local officials said the man, an immigrant from Portugal, tried to flee and harm agents. He and another man were hospitalized after a vehicle they were in crashed.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa and Charlotte Dulany

media:content.media:credit: Kaitlin Newman/The Baltimore Banner, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A shooting in Glen Burnie, Md., involving a U.S. Immigration and Customs officer left two people hospitalized. They were in stable condition, according to ICE.

item.title: Journey to Antarctica Part 2
item.description: To get to the fastest-melting glacier in Antarctica, flying on a helicopter over icy seas is mandatory. Our science reporter Raymond Zhong learns what to do in case of a helicopter crash.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Leila Medina, Thomas Vollkommer, Edward Vega, Jon Hazell, Stephanie Swart and Phil Caller

item.title: After a Plane Crashed in the Texas Fog, 2 Stories of Rescue
item.description: A plane from Mexico was on a medical mission on Monday when it crashed into Galveston Bay, and two men on the water that day helped save two lives.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Sky Decker Jr., via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Multiple people responding to a plane crash near Galveston, Texas, on Monday.

item.title: Nvidia Strikes a Deal With Groq, an A.I. Chip Start-Up
item.description: Nvidia will license Groq’s technology and hire its top executives, adding to the Silicon Valley giant’s heft in artificial intelligence chips.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac and Tripp Mickle

media:content.media:description: Nvidia will hire Groq’s chief executive, Jonathan Ross, and other employees after the companies reached what Groq called a “nonexclusive licensing agreement.”

item.title: The Small Parisian Shop That’s Become a Retail Phenomenon
item.description: With her six-month-old store, Rubirosa’s, the designer Lauren Rubinski offers a colorful take on old-world charm.
item.dc:creator: Alice Cavanagh

item.title: Resultados de las elecciones de Honduras: Nasry Asfura será el próximo presidente
item.description: Nasry Asfura, exalcalde de Tegucigalpa, fue declarado el presidente electo del país centroamericano tras un recuento de votos prolongado después de una contienda reñida.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal and Jeff Ernst

media:content.media:description: Nasry Asfura, del Partido Nacional, tras depositar su voto en Tegucigalpa el 30 de noviembre.

item.title: T Magazine’s Favorite Food Stories of 2025
item.description: From a debate about the best seafood in Tokyo to a recipe for red velvet babka, these are some of the most intriguing and appetizing features we published this year.
item.dc:creator: T Magazine

item.title: Lewis Berman, Veterinarian to the Stars, Is Dead at 90
item.description: He served a New York clientele with names like Kennedy, Kissinger, Fonda, Bacall and Trump by making sure Chappy, Buzzy, Spike and other cherished pets stayed healthy.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Heavy Rain Triggers Flash Floods in Southern California
item.description: An intense winter storm created flash flooding in Southern California, closing roadways and forcing residents to evacuate in parts of the Los Angeles region.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal and Jiawei Wang

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles County workers loading sandbags on Tuesday in preparation for a strong storm in Altadena, Calif.

item.title: Phyllis Lee Levin, Times Fashion Reporter and Biographer, Dies at 104
item.description: Her 1960 essay about the frustrations of educated women prefigured Betty Friedan’s “The Feminine Mystique.” She later wrote books on John Quincy Adams and others.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: The Remarkable Education of John Quincy Adams (Book)

item.title: Honduras Declares Nasry Asfura, Trump Ally, Winner of Presidential Election
item.description: Nasry Asfura was endorsed by President Trump in a contentious election. His opponent, Salvador Nasralla, said he would not accept the results.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal and Jeff Ernst

media:content.media:description: Nasry Asfura, the National Party candidate, cast his vote in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, on Nov. 30.

item.title: Palau Agrees to Take Up to 75 Migrants From the U.S.
item.description: The Pacific nation, with a population of 18,000, overcame the resistance of governmental leaders and advisers, to sign a memorandum of understanding with the U.S., and will get additional aid in return.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Surangel Whipps Jr. of Palau at the U.N. General Assembly in New York in September.

item.title: Trump Tosses Lifelines to the Struggling Coal Industry
item.description: The Energy Department ordered two coal-burning power plants to remain open, and the Environmental Protection Agency gave utilities more time to tackle toxic coal ash.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow

media:content.media:description: Chris Wright, the energy secretary, ordered that two Indiana coal plants, scheduled to close soon, keep running until early 2026.

item.title: The Epstein File Drop Is Not About Justice
item.description: The fight was supposed to be about releasing them. But the way it’s being done seems designed to obscure the truth.
item.dc:creator: Molly Jong-Fast

item.title: A Million More Epstein Documents Have Been Found, Justice Dept. Says
item.description: Democratic lawmakers, who had criticized the Justice Department’s release of the material, accused the Trump administration of violating the law mandating the release of the files.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett and Michael Gold

media:content.media:description: An undated image of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell released by the Justice Department.

item.title: Immigrant Nurse Is Among 2 Dead in Pennsylvania Nursing Home Explosions
item.description: Muthoni Nduthu was one of two killed by explosions at an eastern Pennsylvania facility that was plagued by poor ratings, citations and fines from the federal government.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel, Jack Healy and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

media:content.media:credit: Jose F. Moreno/The Philadelphia Inquirer, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Two people were killed when two explosions tore through a nursing home in Bristol Township, Pa., on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: The Strange Death of Make America Great Again
item.description: Trump has begun to recede from the movement he created.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Walther

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Lee Taete for The New York Times

item.title: Letting ‘Peace on Earth’ Mean Nothing
item.description: A militia accused of genocide has seized a city of a quarter-million people, and it now appears from satellites to be a ghost town.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kristof
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

media:content.media:description: A displaced Sudanese man who fled El-Fasher after the city fell to the Rapid Support Forces.

item.title: California Farmer Arrested in Killing of Wife
item.description: Michael Abatti was charged with fatally shooting Kerri Ann Abatti, who had filed for divorce and was living apart from him in Arizona.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

media:content.media:description: Michael Abatti was arrested in El Centro, Calif., after an Arizona grand jury indicted him on charges that he murdered his wife.

item.title: El despliegue prolongado de portaaviones en el Caribe proyecta la fuerza de EE. UU., y acarrea costos
item.description: El USS Ford lleva seis meses desplegado, ahora en el Caribe, como parte de la campaña de presión del presidente Trump sobre Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: El portaaviones Gerald R. Ford en el mar del Norte en septiembre. Ni la Marina ni el Pentágono han dicho cuándo terminará el despliegue del buque en el Caribe.

item.title: Texas A&M Will Not Reinstate Lecturer Fired Over Gender Lesson
item.description: The decision seemed likely to provoke a court battle in a state where Republican politicians have sought to influence public universities.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder

media:content.media:credit: Timothy Hurst/College Station Eagle, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Texas A&M University has declined to reinstate a faculty member who was fired after she was accused of teaching a course that recognized more than two genders.

item.title: New Charges Could Carry Death Penalty in Attack on National Guard Members in D.C.
item.description: The case against Rahmanullah Lakanwal, an Afghan refugee accused of killing one Guard member and seriously injuring another, was transferred to D.C. District Court, where new firearms charges could bring capital punishment.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg

media:content.media:description: Army Specialist Sarah Beckstrom of the West Virginia National Guard was killed and Air Force Staff Sgt. Andrew Wolfe was seriously wounded near a Washington Metro station last month.

item.title: In Private Letters, Harvard and Trump Administration Escalate Duel
item.description: It is the latest twist in the marquee battle of the administration’s campaign to rein in colleges and universities it views as too liberal.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt, Alan Blinder and Michael C. Bender

media:content.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: An exchange between Linda McMahon, President Trump’s education secretary, and Alan M. Garber, Harvard University’s president, has complicated efforts by the White House and Harvard to end the marquee battle.

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘It’s Not Easy to Please a Woman’
item.description: To celebrate the season, we gathered five of our favorite holiday-themed Tiny Love Stories.

item.title: Luigi Mangione and Tyler Robinson Are a Worrying New Archetype
item.description: They complicate the story about political violence as well as our hopes for safety and justice.
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells

item.title: ‘Marty Supreme’ Review: Timothée Chalamet Sprints to the Top
item.description: The actor stars as a magnetic, striving table-tennis champ in Josh Safdie’s new movie, one of the most exciting movies of the year.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

media:content.media:description: Timothée Chalamet in “Marty Supreme,” set in 1952 New York and directed by Josh Safdie with electrifying flourish.

item.title: How Ukraine Became a Testing Range for A.I. Weapons
item.description: How Ukraine Became a Testing Range for A.I. Weapons

item.title: Mixed Grades for Home-Schooling
item.description: Readers offer personal stories in response to a guest essay critical of home-schooling.

item.title: How a Scholar Nudged the Supreme Court Toward Its Troop Deployment Ruling
item.description: Accepting an argument from a law professor that no party to the case had made, the Supreme Court handed the Trump administration a stinging loss that could lead to more aggressive tactics.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: National Guard members at an immigrant processing and detention center in Broadview, Ill., in October.

item.title: Plan de paz en Ucrania: en qué consiste el proyecto para poner fin a la guerra
item.description: El proyecto abarca una amplia gama de cuestiones, como el territorio, las garantías de seguridad y la reconstrucción de posguerra. Pero Rusia ha mostrado poca disposición a poner fin al conflicto.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut

media:content.media:credit: Nicole Tung para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Soldados ucranianos disparando hacia objetivos rusos en la región de Donetsk en marzo.

item.title: El material censurado de algunos archivos del caso Epstein se puede recuperar fácilmente
item.description: Algunas partes de los archivos publicados sobre el caso no estaban editadas digitalmente de forma adecuada y pueden ser reveladas con facilidad.
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar

media:content.media:credit: Dennis M. Rivera Pichardo para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Los albaceas testamentarios de Jeffrey Epstein se enfrentaron a una demanda civil presentada en las Islas Vírgenes en 2021. Los documentos de la demanda publicados a última hora del lunes incluían algunos que no fueron debidamente censurados digitalmente. Arriba, el tribunal en 2020.

item.title: Shelters Won’t Let My Mother Adopt a Dog. Can I Pretend It’s for Me?
item.description: Which is the more ethical course: honoring the system’s ageist rules, or bending those rules in service of compassion?
item.dc:creator: Kwame Anthony Appiah

item.title: Journey to the Melting Continent
item.description: The New York Times is joining an expedition by sea to Antarctica’s fastest-thinning glaciers.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
